head.headtext: Character evidence—Criminal cases—Other wrongs or acts

para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b) and Fed. R. Evid. 404(b) preclude the admission of evidence of other wrongs or acts to prove the character of a person or to show action in conformity therewith. Evidence, when otherwise admissible for some relevant purpose such as to show motive, knowledge, or intent, does not become inadmissible because it incidentally puts the defendant's character in issue; thus, “O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b) … is, on its face, an evidentiary rule of inclusion which contains a non-exhaustive list of purposes other than bad character for which other acts is deemed relevant and may be properly offered into evidence.”[1]

In the 2015 case of State v. Jones,[2] the Georgia Supreme Court determined that the Court of Appeals erred in excluding evidence of prior acts pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b). In its analysis, the Supreme Court adopted the three-part test used by the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals to determine admissibility of other acts evidence under the corresponding federal rule.[3] In order for such evidence to be admissible, the state must make a showing that:
evidence of extrinsic, or other acts is relevant to an issue other than the defendant's character;
the probative value of the other acts evidence is not substantially outweighed by its unfair prejudice, i.e. the evidence must satisfy the requirements of Rule 403; and
there is sufficient proof so that the jury could find that the defendant committed the act in question.

In State v. Jones,[4] the Supreme Court found that the defendant's prior convictions were relevant in the prosecution of the case and the trial court did not abuse its discretion when it held that evidence of Jones' prior DUI conviction was admissible because a jury could infer from Jones' intent to drive while under the influence on the prior occasion that he possessed the requisite intent on this occasion. Further, the Supreme Court declined to follow the Court of Appeals reasoning that because the charged crimes do not require a defendant to act with a specific intent to commit the crime, the act of whether the defendant drove under the influence on another occasion was irrelevant. The Court concluded, “consistent with the underlying principles of the rule prohibiting other acts evidence offered for an impermissible purpose, that other acts evidence may be relevant under Rule 404(b), without regard to whether the charged crime is one requiring a specific or general intent, when it is offered for the permissible purpose of showing a criminal defendant's intent and knowledge. [Cit.] Such evidence is relevant if the State articulates a clear hypothesis showing that the evidence offered has any tendency to prove or disprove the existence of any consequential fact independent of the use forbidden by Rule 404(b). See OCGA § 24-4-401.” The Court, however, remanded the case to the Court of Appeals for its consideration of whether the trial court erred in its evaluation of the admissibility of the defendant's prior convictions based on the considerations set out in Rule 403: prejudice, confusion or waste of time.[5]

In State v. Atkins,[6] the Georgia Supreme Court admonished the trial court and held the trial court abused its discretion when it excluded evidence “in an abundance of caution,” which is not a permissible reason under Rule 403, and because the court's analysis was overbroad, since the court determined that the state tendered the evidence for all the reasons included in the analysis under Rule 404, not just the reasons given by the state.

Evidence of gang affiliation has been deemed relevant to show how the defendants knew one another, to provide context and motive for the defendants' joint participation in the robbery, to explain the distribution of the robbery proceeds among the defendants, and to explain the defendant's conduct after the crime.[7]

Evidence of disciplinary reports filed against an inmate while in prison are admissible and relevant to explain why that inmate was terminated from a program and that he alleged in a warrant application that the officer had caused his termination, where the inmate was convicted of false statements or writings, even though said reports may place his character in issue.[8]

In Griffin v. State,[9] the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed that the trial court properly admitted evidence that defendant was angry with the murder victim over a drug debt, since the evidence was relevant to the issue of motive regardless of whether it incidentally placed the defendant's character at issue. The prosecution in a criminal proceeding must provide reasonable notice to the defense in advance of trial, unless pretrial notice is excused by the court upon good cause shown, of the general nature of any character evidence it intends to introduce at trial. However, notice is not required when the evidence of prior crimes, wrongs, or acts is offered to prove the circumstances immediately surrounding the charged crime, motive, or prior difficulties between the accused and the alleged victim.[10] Testimony from a previous trial or necessity testimony may be offered as other crimes evidence when U.S. Constitutional confrontation clause issues have been addressed, especially regarding sexual offenses.[11] In Moore v. State,[12] the Georgia Court of Appeals held admissible evidence of two rapes to which the defendant had pled guilty where the defendant had approached victims at a bus stop and forced them to enter a wooded area. Police officers' testimony about the victim's statements was admissible out of necessity because one victim had died and the other victim could not be located. The defendant's Sixth Amendment rights were not violated because he had waived his right to cross-examine the witnesses when he pled guilty.

The Georgia Supreme Court has further allowed other acts evidence of a defendant's prior assault and battery of his ex-girlfriends, where the charges against the defendant included malice murder and aggravated assault, reasoning that the intent, while not the same for some of the charges, was the same for other charges.[13]
In Maqrouf v. State[14] the Court of Appeals reversed the trial court when it admitted evidence of the defendant molesting one child in the prosecution of cruelty to defendant's other daughter.

In Jackson v. State,[15] the trial court erred in admitting evidence of a prior shooting which occurred 10 years prior to the shooting in the case, where the circumstances of both incidents were analyzed for their similarities, but not their differences, and where there was a lack of prosecutorial need for the evidence adduced.

O.C.G.A. §§ 24-4-413, 24-4-414 and 24-4-415, pertain to the admission of prior offenses in criminal sexual assault cases, child molestation cases, and civil sexual assault or child molestation proceedings respectively. Likewise, Fed. R. Evid. 413, 414, and 415 specifically address the admissibility of other offense evidence in sexual assault and child molestation cases. These provisions supersede the general rule for the admission of evidence of other crimes. The statutes provide that evidence of prior acts may be admitted in these cases and consider for its bearing on any matter to which it is relevant. The state must provide at least 10 day's notice to the defense, and must disclose the evidence.

The Court of Appeals has reasoned that the statutory language of the provision was intended to create a rule of inclusion with a strong presumption in favor of admissibility, so evidence of a past conviction for statutory rape was admissible in a case for statutory rape and child molestation.[16] In Kritlow v. State,[17] the court held that although lustful disposition is not one of the specific purposes set out under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b), the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 24-4-413 supersede the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b) in sexual assault cases. In State v. McPherson,[18] the court held the trial court abused its discretion when it excluded similar transaction evidence of prior molestations, even though the acts were committed 35 years earlier. The court reasoned that excluding similar transaction evidence pursuant to Rule 403 was erroneous because the exclusionary rule is to be used sparingly, and in child molestation cases, the legislature concluded that such evidence shall be admissible to prove intent. In Dixon v. State,[19] the Court of Appeals acknowledges that neither the Georgia courts, nor the 11th Circuit, have expressly decided whether evidence admitted under Rule 413 should be evaluated under a different type of Rule 403 balance that weighs in favor of admission. However, the Court of Appeals disallowed evidence of prior convictions from out of state where the state failed to prove that the out-of-state convictions constituted an offense within the purview of O.C.G.A. § 24-4-413 or O.C.G.A. § 24-4-414.[20]

Under the new Code, “bent of mind” is no longer an exception to similar acts evidence. Thus, the Georgia General Assembly added O.C.G.A. § 24-4-417 to describe the situations under which a DUI defendant's prior DUI would be admissible.[21] In Frost v. State,[22] the trial court did not abuse its discretion when it found that the evidence that Frost had driven under the influence on two prior occasions was “relevant to prove knowledge.” The Court of Appeals has also answered in the affirmative that the admissibility under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-417 of the accused's commission of other similar offenses, if relevant, should be analyzed under Rule 403.[23] Furthermore, the Court of Appeals has held that under Rule 417, the defendant need not have been convicted of DUI for the prior driving incident to be admissible.[24]

The admissibility of extrinsic transactions has never been one of mere similarity, but of relevance to the issues in the trial of the case. The state has the burden of showing a logical connection between crimes which are essentially dissimilar.”[25] Thus, courts are charged to look at the similarities as well as the differences between transactions.[26] When determining whether a prior transaction is sufficiently similar to the offense charged, courts “must focus on the similarities of the occurrences rather than their differences.”[27] Moreover, the Court of Appeals will sometimes overlook the error of admitting the evidence and hold it is harmless where there is overwhelming evidence of guilt otherwise.[28]

Also, there is “no requirement that to be admissible the similar act must have occurred prior to the act on which the defendant is being tried.”[29] Moreover, there is no prohibition to admitting a conviction that has been overturned, or evidence of charges that resulted in an acquittal.[30]
The other crimes may have occurred before or after the charged conduct.[31] A subsequent uncharged automobile theft was admissible in a prosecution for theft by taking automobile.

A defendant's words may be admissible as a similar act where the utterance itself constituted a crime.[32] Also, utterances may be admissible where they reflect prior difficulties between the defendant and the victim.[33] Generally, an accused's statements are not “independent offenses or acts” for the purposes of similar act evidence unless those statements in and of themselves constitute a crime.[34]

O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b) requires the prosecution to give reasonable notice to the defense in advance of trial of its intent to present evidence of “other crimes, wrongs, or acts” unless the court excuses such notice upon good cause shown. State v. Battle[35] provides guidance on the framework to be used when giving notice of Rule 404(b) evidence.

In Brooks, where the defendant was tried for the murder of a security guard who was bound and gagged and shot seven times during the commission of a robbery, the Court held inadmissible evidence of a prior murder where the same defendant had pled guilty to the murder of a policeman, where the policeman was shot twice in the back after a traffic stop.

App. 444, 444, 512 S.E.2d 343 (1999), affirming a finding of substantial similarity between drug offenses where both incidents occurred at night, in the same area, involved the same drug in amounts greater than that generally possessed for personal use and tended to show that the defendant would deny all knowledge of contraband when caught in its proximity.

State, 275 Ga. 232, 564 S.E.2d 198 (2002) (prior difficulties, such as threats, are admissible when defendant is accused of criminal act against the victim).

Newsome v. State, 288 Ga. 647, 706 S.E.2d 436 (2011), where testimony that defendant told witnesses that he wanted to go to a “shot house” so that he could rob it, in days prior to some shootings, was not similar transaction evidence. Defendant never attempted to rob a shot house, and his statement to witness was neither crime in and of itself, nor expression of prior difficulties between defendant and any victims of charged crimes.
